g.text: Matsui M, Kuwata H, Mori D,
Department of Chemical Science and Engineering, Kobe University, Kobe, Japan,
Passivation of magnesium metal anode is one of the critical challenges for
the development of magnesium batteries. Here we investigated the passivation
process of an intermetallic anode: Mg
synthesized by solid-state and thin ﬁlm
composite electrode shows excellent reversibility in magnesium
bis(triﬂuoromethansulfonylamide) dissolved in acetonitrile, while Mg
same crystal structure and similar chemical properties, is electrochemically inactive.
thin ﬁlm electrodes, which show reversibility with low
overpotential not only in the acetonitrile solution but also glyme-based solutions. Surface
layer corresponding to the decomposed TFSA anion is slightly suppressed in the case
thin ﬁlm electrode, compared with Mg metal. Comparative study of
anodes are not completely passivated. The bond valence sum mapping of the Mg
The electrochemical properties of the Mg
anode is mainly due to the less passivation
Keywords: intermetallics, anode, passivation layer, hydrolysis, bond-valence sum mapping, Mg
Beyond Li-ion batteries have been widely investigated last decade (
). Alternative anode active material using electrochemical deposition-dissolution process of
less-noble metal is one strategy for the development of high-energy battery system (
). Among various choices of the less-noble metal anodes, magnesium is one of the potential
candidates as the high-energy anode active material, because the volumetric capacity: 3,800 mAh
is 1.9 times higher than that of lithiummetal, and no dendritic growth during the deposition
). On the other hand, the surface of the magnesiummetal is easily passivated
in conventional electrolyte solutions such as magnesium perchlorate dissolved in propylene
). Therefore, the choice of the electrolyte solutions for rechargeable
magnesiumbatteries is very limited. Typically the organohaloaluminate electrolyte solutions, which
are widely studied by Aurbach et al. in early 2000s (e.g.,
